questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of milky discharge from both breasts. She has not had pain in her breasts. She has had nipple piercings for 6 months and reports mild discomfort when wearing tight clothing. She has a 5-year history of hypothyroidism and a 7-year history of migraines. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow; her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. Current medications are levothyroxine and propranolol. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.78°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg. On breast examination, a milky discharge can be expressed from the nipples bilaterally. The skin around the nipple piercings appears normal. There are no palpable breast masses. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. A serum pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Various medications can lead to hyperprolactinemia, but propranolol does not. Drugs known to cause hyperprolactinemia include antipsychotics (e.g., chlorpromazine, haloperidol), antiemetics (e.g., metoclopramide), tricyclic antidepressants, antihypertensives (e.g., verapamil, methyldopa), H2 receptor antagonists, opioid analgesics, oral contraceptive pills, and cocaine. In addition, prolactin levels should be measured before discontinuing a medication.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography is indicated in patients ≥ 30 years of age with red flags in nipple discharge (e.g., unilateral and/or bloody discharge, risk factors for breast cancer) to evaluate for lactiferous duct abnormalities. This diagnostic modality is not used in the workup of galactorrhea with no red flags.

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the head can be used to assess the pituitary gland in patients with suspected prolactinoma, which can cause galactorrhea and headaches. However, patients with prolactinoma typically present with irregular menses and/or bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm, which are not seen here. While an MRI of the head may be considered later in the diagnostic workup, it is not the most appropriate next step at this stage.

D) INCORRECT:

Follow-up and reassurance are the recommended management for physiological causes of galactorrhea. Although this patient presents with no red flags in nipple discharge, further testing is needed to rule out systemic causes before determining the appropriate treatment approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for detecting breast abnormalities in patients < 30 years of age and is indicated in this patient group if there are red flags in nipple discharge (e.g., unilateral and/or bloody discharge, risk factors for breast cancer) to evaluate for lactiferous duct abnormalities. This imaging modality is not used in the workup of galactorrhea with no red flags.

F) CORRECT:

Evaluation of patients with nipple discharge and no red flags typically starts with a pregnancy test. If the pregnancy test is negative, measurement of serum prolactin levels is indicated. In patients with hyperprolactinemic galactorrhea, follow-up diagnostics for hyperprolactinemia are warranted. These include thyroid and liver function tests, measurement of serum creatinine levels, assessment for medication-related adverse effects, and MRI of the pituitary gland (for suspected pituitary adenoma). Given this patient's history, thyroid function tests are recommended to exclude poorly controlled hypothyroidism as a cause of hyperprolactinemia.

If hyperprolactinemia workup reveals no abnormalities, galactorrhea is most likely caused by increased sensitivity to nipple stimulation (e.g., due to piercings or ill-fitting clothing), known as physiological hyperprolactinemia. The recommended management is to avoid nipple stimulation, and reassess in 3 months.
questions.hint: This patient presents with physiological nipple discharge (bilateral, milky) unrelated to pregnancy or breastfeeding (i.e., galactorrhea). Red flags in nipple discharge include nonmilky appearance, unilateral involvement, risk factors for breast cancer, and a palpable breast mass.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of small quantities of intermittent, blood-tinged discharge from her left nipple. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. Her last menstrual period was 12 days ago. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. Physical examination shows scant serosanguinous fluid expressible from the left nipple. There is no palpable breast mass or axillary lymphadenopathy. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in premenopausal women can cause galactorrhea (bilateral nonbloody discharge). Common causes of physiological hyperprolactinemia include pregnancy and emotional stress, while those of pathological hyperprolactinemia include pituitary adenoma (manifests with headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia) or intake of certain drugs (e.g., antipsychotics, SSRIs). This patient has no history to suggest either physiological or pathological hyperprolactinemia and presents with unilateral sanguineous nipple discharge, which warrants a different workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Ductography is indicated in patients who present with pathological nipple discharge if other imaging is inconclusive or shows features suspicious of malignancy (e.g., ductal irregularity). Ductography is not routinely indicated for the evaluation of pathological nipple discharge because it is expensive, exposes the patient to radiation, and is technically difficult to perform. Also, most causes of nipple discharge in women < 30 years of age are benign.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with red flags for nipple discharge should be evaluated with imaging studies for lactiferous duct pathologies. Patients > 30 years of age should undergo ultrasonography AND diagnostic mammography to detect signs of ductal abnormalities (e.g., dilated ducts, ductal mass/nodule). For patients < 30 years of age, subareolar breast ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality; because breast tissue density is higher in this age group, a mammogram is less effective at detecting small lesions. Also, there is no ionizing radiation exposure associated with ultrasound imaging, unlike during a mammogram. If imaging reveals signs of malignancy, a biopsy of the lesion is indicated. Nonmilky nipple discharge is most commonly caused by benign conditions, such as intraductal papilloma or ductal ectasia, but may also be a sign of underlying malignancy (e.g., ductal carcinoma in situ).

In nonpregnant patients with bilateral, milky (nonbloody) nipple discharge (galactorrhea), laboratory assessment with measurement of serum prolactin levels is the first diagnostic step to evaluate for hyperprolactinemia.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

D) INCORRECT:

An image-guided biopsy can be performed in the diagnostic workup of patients with unilateral, nonmilky nipple discharge. However, this diagnostic step is reserved for those with evidence of malignancy (e.g., irregularity of a duct wall) on prior imaging studies.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytological examination of nipple discharge is not recommended because of its low sensitivity in detecting malignancy, high false-negative rates (a negative cytology does not definitively rule out malignancy), and low-cost effectiveness. In addition, cytology, if positive, does not help localize the lesion nor differentiate between an in situ and invasive carcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Mammography is recommended for the evaluation of focal breast findings (e.g., unilateral nipple discharge) in women > 30 years of age. However, this imaging modality is not recommended as the first-line diagnostic test in patients < 30 years of age. Breast tissue is very dense in this group, limiting the efficacy of mammograms to detect small lesions. Furthermore, mammography exposes the patient to ionizing radiation. Finally, the incidence of breast cancer in women < 30 years of age is low. Another diagnostic test for the evaluation of nipple discharge is, therefore, more appropriate in this patient group.

G) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is indicated in patients with nipple discharge that is consistent with normoprolactinemic galactorrhea. This condition manifests with bilateral milky discharge and normal prolactin levels. This patient, however, presents with unilateral, nonmilky nipple discharge, which requires further investigation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with red flags for nipple discharge (unilateral, spontaneous, and serosanguineous nipple discharge).

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with bilateral nipple discharge for the past week. The patient reports that the discharge looks milky and only occurs when pressure is applied to her breasts. Her mother was recently diagnosed with breast cancer at age 50, and the patient is very worried that she might also have the condition.
The patient is often tired and has occasional headaches, which she attributes to school stress and lack of sleep. She reports no pain, redness, or itching of the breast, fever, visual changes, nausea, abdominal pain, or problems with bowel or bladder function. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and has been taking a combined oral contraceptive pill for pregnancy prevention for the past 6 months. Menstrual cycles are regular every 28 days, and she has not missed any periods. One year ago, she was diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder and started on fluoxetine, which she feels has helped immensely. The patient occasionally drinks alcohol and smokes marijuana once per month but reports no tobacco or other drug use.
Vital signs are within normal limits. A few drops of milky discharge can be expressed from multiple ducts of both breasts. There are no visible or palpable breast abnormalities and no axillary lymphadenopathy. Ophthalmologic and neurologic examinations are normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and thyroid-stimulating hormone level are normal. Prolactin is measured at 50 ng/mL (reference range, 0–30). Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the pituitary
Measure follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone levels
Switch the fluoxetine to sertraline, and then recheck prolactin
Switch the oral contraceptive to a progesterone-only contraceptive, and then recheck prolactin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for detecting breast abnormalities in patients <30 years of age. Although ultrasound is used in the workup of unilateral and/or bloody nipple discharge to evaluate for pathologies of the breast, it is not indicated in patients with bilateral, non-bloody nipple discharge (i.e., galactorrhea), which typically has a systemic cause.

B) CORRECT:

Bilateral, multiductal, milky nipple discharge in non-lactating individuals is called galactorrhea. Galactorrhea can be due to excessive manual stimulation of the breasts, medication effects, prolactinoma, other pituitary or hypothalamic lesions, hypothyroidism, or kidney or liver failure. This condition is usually associated with elevated prolactin levels, which inhibit GnRH secretion, leading to decreased FSH and LH. This can cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, resulting in amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, and/or sexual dysfunction. This patient’s periods may have remained regular due to the effects of her combined oral contraceptive pill.

Pregnancy should be ruled out in premenopausal patients with galactorrhea after history is obtained and a clinical examination is performed. Laboratory assessment with measurement of serum prolactin levels is the next diagnostic step to evaluate for hyperprolactinemia. Non-pregnant patients with hyperprolactinemia should undergo further laboratory workup including serum TSH levels, creatinine, and liver function testing to assess for hypothyroidism and other secondary causes of prolactinemia. Ophthalmologic testing should be performed to assess for signs of compression of the optic chiasm due to pituitary or hypothalamic tumors. If a medication is strongly suspected as the underlying cause, it should be stopped or changed, and prolactin levels should be remeasured. A pituitary MRI with contrast should be performed to rule out pituitary and hypothalamic lesions when hyperprolactinemia is not clearly attributable to another cause.

Key learning point: In a female adolescent with galactorrhea and hyperprolactinemia that is not clearly attributable to a medication, the workup should include: a pregnancy test, TSH, and magnetic resonance imaging of the pituitary.

C) INCORRECT:

Sex hormones, including estrogen, testosterone, FSH, and LH, should be measured in patients with signs of hypogonadism, which this patient does not have. Moreover, her FSH and LH levels are likely suppressed because she is taking combined oral contraceptive pills.

D) INCORRECT:

If a medication is strongly suspected to be the underlying cause of nipple discharge, it should be discontinued or changed to a medication with a lower likelihood of increasing prolactin levels before these levels are remeasured. Although selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) use has in rare cases been associated with galactorrhea, this patient has been taking fluoxetine for a year without symptoms, making it an unlikely cause. Furthermore, since any SSRI may have this effect, switching from one to another is unlikely to improve this patient's symptoms.

Medications associated with hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea include antipsychotics, antiemetics, and antihypertensives (in particular methyldopa).

E) INCORRECT:

If a medication is strongly suspected to be the underlying cause of nipple discharge, it should be discontinued or changed, and prolactin levels should be remeasured. Although increased levels of estrogen are associated with hyperprolactinemia, the amount of estrogen found in combined oral contraceptives is low and unlikely to have this effect. Furthermore, this patient has been taking an oral contraceptive for six months without symptoms, making it an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of a light greenish, milky discharge from both breasts. There is no mastalgia. She has hypothyroidism and migraine headaches. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow; her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. Current medications include levothyroxine and propranolol. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.78°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Breast examination is unremarkable. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Serum studies show normal prolactine and thyroid-stimulating hormone levels. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mammogram is indicated in patients ≥ 30 years old with unilateral and/or bloody nipple discharge to evaluate for lactiferous duct abnormalities. It is not used in the workup of galactorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the head can be used to evaluate for pituitary adenomas, including prolactinomas, which can lead to galactorrhea. Prolactinoma causes hyperprolactinemia and may manifest with irregular menses due to subsequent dysregulation of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone. This patient has normal prolactin levels and regular menses, which suggest a different cause of galactorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Nipple discharge cytology is not recommended because it has a high false-negative rate and is not cost-effective. This patient has bilateral nipple discharge, which suggests a benign cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for detecting breast abnormalities in patients < 30 years of age. Although ultrasound is used in the workup of unilateral and/or bloody nipple discharge to evaluate for possible lactiferous duct abnormalities, it is not indicated in patients with bilateral, nonbloody nipple discharge (i.e., galactorrhea), which typically has a systemic cause.

E) CORRECT:

Normoprolactinemic galactorrhea is a type of nonpathological nipple discharge that may be the result of chronic nipple stimulation (e.g., due to piercing or ill-fitting clothing). The most appropriate next steps in management are reassurance that the condition is benign and follow-up. Galactorrhea typically manifests with bilateral, milky nipple discharge that is usually white but may sometimes be green or clear. If the discharge is unilateral and/or bloody, imaging studies (subareolar ultrasound or mammography) are indicated to evaluate for lactiferous duct abnormalities.

In cases of suspected or confirmed hyperprolactinemic galactorrhea, workup includes measuring serum β-hCG levels to exclude pregnancy, serum creatinine levels to exclude chronic kidney failure, and serum thyroid-stimulating hormone levels to exclude uncontrolled hypothyroidism (which can lead to hyperprolactinemia). Magnetic resonance imaging of the pituitary gland may be indicated in patients with suspected pituitary adenoma.
questions.hint: Bilateral, nonbloody nipple discharge in a nonpregnant, nonbreastfeeding patient with normal serum prolactin levels and a normal physical examination is consistent with normoprolactinemic galactorrhea.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a three-week history of intermittent milky fluid discharge from her nipples and a two-month history of skipped menstrual periods. She has never been pregnant and reports no headaches or visual disturbances. Physical examination shows expressible milky discharge from the breasts bilaterally (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Human chorionic gonadotropin
0.3 mIU/mL
< 5 mIU/mL



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used to evaluate suspicious breast lesions, especially in higher-risk populations. This patient has bilateral milky discharge and amenorrhea, suggesting an endocrine disorder like hyperprolactinemia, not breast malignancy. The absence of unilateral symptoms or palpable masses reduces mammography's utility here.

B) CORRECT:

Galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities suggest a disorder of prolactin regulation. Elevated serum prolactin can stimulate milk production and inhibit gonadotropin-releasing hormone, disrupting luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone secretion, leading to menstrual abnormalities. Measuring serum prolactin quantifies its level and guides further investigation into potential causes, such as a pituitary adenoma or other hyperprolactinemia causes.

Key learning point: In cases of galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities, measuring prolactin levels is the first step to evaluate for hyperprolactinemia.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

C) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound evaluates pelvic structures but does not assess the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, where the likely pathology lies. The patient's galactorrhea and amenorrhea suggest an endocrine issue, directing the workup towards serum prolactin measurement rather than uterine or ovarian imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

While serum gonadotropin levels assess the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, they are more useful in primary ovarian disorders. In hyperprolactinemia, excess prolactin inhibits gonadotropin-releasing hormone, leading to reduced gonadotropin levels. Measuring these levels does not address the underlying prolactin-related abnormality.

No other abnormalities are found on examination. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum prolactin levels are indicated to screen for hyperprolactinemia if the patient has bilateral milky discharge. This patient presents with unilateral sanguineous nipple discharge, which warrants a different initial step in workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Cytological examination of nipple discharge is not recommended because of its low sensitivity in detecting malignancy, high false-negative rates (a negative cytology does not definitively rule out malignancy), and low-cost effectiveness. In addition, cytology, if positive, does not help localize the lesion nor differentiate between an in situ and invasive carcinoma.

Another diagnostic test for the evaluation of nipple discharge is, therefore, more appropriate in this patient group.

D) INCORRECT:
